posts.name: RyanShoff
posts.cooked:
We’ve integrated 971’s Cuda Apriltag detector into Photonvision. Testing it on the Nvidia Jetson Orin Nano Superduper Developer Kit shows promise, allowing other teams access. Further refinement is needed before it joins the main repository.

There are three GitHub repositories relevant to our setup:

1. **Photonvision Fork**: Available at [Jetson Orin Branch](https://github.com/FRC-Team-4143/photonvision/tree/jetson-orin).
2. **971 GPU Detector Wrapper**: Found in [GpuDetectorJNI](https://github.com/FRC-Team-4143/GpuDetectorJNI).
3. **Innovision OV9281 Camera Driver**: Accessible via [ov9281kernelmods](https://github.com/FRC-Team-4143/ov9281kernelmods).

The CUDA Apriltag library and camera driver offer compiled binaries. A USB camera isn’t required if using them.

To set things up, install the CUDA library in `/usr/bin` and clone the Photonvision branch. Execute `./gradlew buildAndCopyUI` followed by `./gradlew run`. This should launch the ApriltagCuda pipeline, detailed further in the Photonvision documentation.

Important notes include compatibility requirements: this setup works specifically for newer Jetson Orin Nanos, uses the OV9281 camera driver exclusively, requires Jetpack 6.2, and some UI controls lack functionality.

posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked: Do you have any numbers for performance?

posts.name: Cole Hunt
posts.cooked: Our test bench features two CSI cameras with resolutions of approximately 1280x720, operating at roughly 55 FPS each. @Coalman321 may provide further details on this specific aspect of the testing process.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Hello, looking promising! Only notes so far are that at some point we should probably patch to support OpenCV 8 unless just nulling out higher-order terms is valid. Once we have CI working, happy to move these repos into the photon github organization as well so we can put artifacts into our Maven server like we do for libcamera drivers.

posts.name: Coalman321
posts.cooked:
Current setup uses two OV9281 Monochrome cameras at 1280x800 resolution. The images are processed via a custom kernel module driver on Jetpack 6.1/6.2. Without additional processing, the system operates at approximately 144 FPS per camera. Jetsons are configured in MAXN Super mode with a cooling fan setting. The Orin Nanos is utilized instead of its larger sibling, the Orin NX, for consistency.

The system currently achieves simultaneous detection rates of 55 FPS on each camera, with a combined latency of 30–40 ms, dominated by a GPU-based detector contributing around 15 ms. Performance-wise, the algorithm matches or exceeds the original CPU-based implementation, utilizing roughly 85–95% of available GPU bandwidth when running detection pipelines.

I'm attempting to gauge how this compares to existing boards. I'm curious if the hardware table available here is current.  
It’s known that the orange Pi 5 struggles to maintain 60 fps when handling multiple cameras. Thus, operating at 55 fps with two cameras appears superior to what I’m aware of.

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked: Awesome. This certainly seems easier than using isaac_ros-apriltag... Edit: Using two USB OV9281 cameras at 1280x800, it runs at around 36 FPS with ~26ms latency. The CPU apriltag pipeline runs at 18 FPS with 60ms latency, so this is quite the improvement.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: The hardware table here is outdated. The last column in the spreadsheet shows the software version, giving a rough idea of when it was used. There’s no formal test to check if same-hardware-software changes affect processing performance, but I’d expect the ‘scream test’ to fail if common combos drop performance.

posts.name: Austin Schuh

posts.name: JC Li
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text:

```
I'm attempting to set up a project using my Jetson Orin Nx 16G module on a Seeed Studio J401 carrier board. The system has been configured with JetPack 6.1 (L4T 36.4.0) and OpenCV 4.11.0 using CUDA 12.6.

I followed the Photonvision fork and branch on GitHub, specifically the jetson-orin repository, along with the GpuDetectorJNI library adapted for photonvision. I'm using an IMX219 CSI camera, which comes pre-installed with the Jetpack drivers on the SBC.

I integrated the following configuration into QuirkyCamera.java:
```
new QuirkyCamera(
    -1,
    -1,
    "vi-output, imx219 9-0010",
    "IMX219 CSI Camera",
    CameraQuirk.Gain
);
```

When running `./gradlew run`, the camera appears accessible locally on port 5800. However, activating it resulted in an error:

```
UnsatisfiedLinkError: 'int org.photonvision.raspi.LibCameraJNI.getSensorModelRaw'
```

This error occurred during the creation of the VisionSource for the CSI camera, indicating issues with initializing the LibcameraGpuSource. Despite efforts to troubleshoot, I couldn't resolve the underlying cause.

Upon analysis, it seems the ZeroCopyPicam camera type is the most suitable option based on availability and compatibility considerations.
```

posts.name: JC Li
posts.cooked:
According to the Camera Matching document, V4L-connected cameras are assumed to be on a USB bus rather than a CSI bus. Since the CSI bus relies on the libcamera library, which isn't supported by Jetson platforms, only USB cameras can be used on Jetson, which is somewhat limiting.  
It would be helpful to understand why V4L isn’t compatible with CSI cameras, especially since V4L does support /dev/videoX devices akin to CSI functionality.

posts.name: JC Li
posts.cooked: I think I figured it out. Things are complicated. The PV guys maintain a dedicated libcamera Java package available on GitHub at https://github.com/PhotonVision/photon-libcamera-gl-driver. To support Jetson CSI cameras, I need to wrap libargus/gstreamer APIs and others into a Java package, release it, and create a library loader within the PV app to automatically load it and access the wrapped C++ APIs. While it requires significant effort, it’s straightforward enough.

posts.name: Bill Kinahan
posts.cooked:
To address the issue with reading images from OV9281RAW-V2 cameras connected via CSI on a Jetson Orin Nano, consider the following structured approach:

1. **CSI Processing**: Ensure your code processes CSI streams independently of USB-based providers. Asynchronous processing may require additional delays or checks to avoid timeouts.

2. **Driver Compatibility**: Verify that the OV9281 drivers are compatible with your current software versions. Check for known issues or community discussions regarding CSI usage.

3. **Debugging Techniques**:
   - **Logging**: Add logs to track frame reception times and system responses.
   - **Debugger Use**: Step through the code to identify exact points of failure.

4. **Multiple Camera Configuration**: Confirm correct setup for dual CSI cameras, possibly involving synchronization or role assignment (master/slave).

5. **Resource Management**: Optimize task scheduling and allocate sufficient resources to reduce network latency or contention.

By systematically addressing these areas, you can pinpoint the cause of the timeout errors and ensure smooth operation of your vision system on the Jetson platform.
